values.title: camera lighting problem on heightmaps due to race condition with laser

content.raw:
There seems to be a race condition that causes problems with rendering of diffuse light on heightmaps with the camera sensor. When a laser sensor gets subscribed to before the camera sensor then lighting on heightmaps induced by diffuse light sources seems to be disabled in the camera sensor and only ambient light is rendered. Adding and removing light sources then seems to toggle rendering of diffuse light on/off, however this behaviour is non-deterministic, e.g. sometimes removing a previously added light source disables rendering of diffuse light and sometimes it doesn't.

Here a video illustrating the bug using the current head of gazebo_1.8 and drcsim_2.6: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=h71wf0hd3gc
content.html:
There seems to be a race condition that causes problems with rendering of diffuse light on heightmaps with the camera sensor. When a laser sensor gets subscribed to before the camera sensor then lighting on heightmaps induced by diffuse light sources seems to be disabled in the camera sensor and only ambient light is rendered. Adding and removing light sources then seems to toggle rendering of diffuse light on/off, however this behaviour is non-deterministic, e.g. sometimes removing a previously added light source disables rendering of diffuse light and sometimes it doesn't.

Here a video illustrating the bug using the current head of gazebo_1.8 and drcsim_2.6: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=h71wf0hd3gc

for a hinge joint a SetMaxForce function, doesn't make sense and it also has no influence in the code, so it created some confusion to me at first (should maybe be removed), what is actually checked and makes sense to me is:

// truncate effort if effortLimit is not negative
if (this->effortLimit[_index] >= 0)
_effort = math::clamp(_effort,
    -this->effortLimit[_index], this->effortLimit[_index]);

therefore there should be a function called SetMaxTorque instead, where one can set the effortLimit, which currently can only be set through sdf.

I only checked it for hinge joints, because this are the ones we're using, but this probably also applies for other joint types.

let me know if I should create a pull request, I just wasn't sure if I missed something ;)

content.raw:
I've been seeing occasional failures of the transport_stress performance test since pull request #548. In my overnight `make test` loop, I see about 10% failures of TransportStress.ManyNodes, and Jenkins has seen two as well ([gazebo-default-quantal 206](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-default-devel-quantal-amd64/206/testReport/%28root%29/TransportStressTest/ManyNodes/) and [gazebo-1.8-precise 19](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo_1.8/job/gazebo-gazebo_1.8-devel-precise-amd64/19/testReport/junit/%28root%29/TransportStressTest/ManyNodes/)).

The test fails by taking too long to publish the 20000 messages. Here's the time it took 7 failing tests out of 62 total attempts:
~~~
87: Msg Time to publish 20000 = 1 947009733
87: Msg Time to publish 20000 = 1 866240790
87: Msg Time to publish 20000 = 1 463577621
87: Msg Time to publish 20000 = 2 292999867
87: Msg Time to publish 20000 = 2 276908435
87: Msg Time to publish 20000 = 1 877051755
87: Msg Time to publish 20000 = 2 369845797
~~~
Perhaps the [removal of the TBB code in pull request #548](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/548/transport-performance-update/diff#Lgazebo/transport/TopicManager.ccT162) is the cause?
content.html:
I've been seeing occasional failures of the transport_stress performance test since pull request #548. In my overnight make test loop, I see about 10% failures of TransportStress.ManyNodes, and Jenkins has seen two as well (gazebo-default-quantal 206 and gazebo-1.8-precise 19).

The test fails by taking too long to publish the 20000 messages. Here's the time it took 7 failing tests out of 62 total attempts:

87: Msg Time to publish 20000 = 1 947009733
87: Msg Time to publish 20000 = 1 866240790
87: Msg Time to publish 20000 = 1 463577621
87: Msg Time to publish 20000 = 2 292999867
87: Msg Time to publish 20000 = 2 276908435
87: Msg Time to publish 20000 = 1 877051755
87: Msg Time to publish 20000 = 2 369845797

Perhaps the removal of the TBB code in pull request #548 is the cause?

content.raw:
We're seeing segmentation faults in Gazebo intermittently.  The most common situation seems to be running a VRC world with logging enabled.  We'll collect evidence here.

Debug procedure: after a crash, there should be a core file at `~/.ros/core`, so:

    sudo apt-get install gdb
    gdb gzserver ~/.ros/core
    bt

Also grab the last line of the score log, to get the time elapsed.  E.g. if the run was vrc_task_2:

    tail -n1  /tmp/vrc_task_2/score.log
content.html:

Debug procedure: after a crash, there should be a core file at ~/.ros/core, so:

sudo apt-get install gdb
gdb gzserver ~/.ros/core
bt

Also grab the last line of the score log, to get the time elapsed. E.g. if the run was vrc_task_2:

tail -n1  /tmp/vrc_task_2/score.log

values.title: Seg-fault with pr2 in a VRC world

values.title: gzstats segfault when node can't find namespace

content.raw:
gzstats can seg-fault when its transport node can't find a namespace, which may occur when the master is running slowly (such as with valgrind).

Console output:
~~~
$ gzstats
Msg Waiting for master.....................................................................
Msg Connected to gazebo master @ http://127.0.0.1:11345
Msg Publicized address: 192.168.1.67
Error [ConnectionManager.cc:507] Unable to get namespaces from master
Error [Node.cc:82] No namespace found
Segmentation fault (core dumped)
~~~

Backtrace
~~~
(gdb) bt
#0  __memcpy_ssse3_back ()
    at ../sysdeps/x86_64/multiarch/memcpy-ssse3-back.S:1579
#1  0x00007fd24bf3fe29 in std::string::append(std::string const&) ()
   from /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libstdc++.so.6
#2  0x00000000004396e9 in std::operator+<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> > (__lhs=0x7fd24ce81718 "/gazebo/", __rhs=...)
    at /usr/include/c++/4.6/bits/basic_string.tcc:704
#3  0x00007fd24ce59045 in gazebo::transport::Node::DecodeTopicName (
    this=0x2623c40, _topic=...)
    at /home/scpeters/osrf/gazebo_1.8/gazebo/transport/Node.cc:104
#4  0x000000000042fcd7 in gazebo::transport::Node::Subscribe<gazebo::msgs::WorldStatistics> (this=0x2623c40, _topic=..., 
    _fp=0x429f84 <cb(boost::shared_ptr<gazebo::msgs::WorldStatistics const> cons---Type <return> to continue, or q <return> to quit---
t&)>, _latching=false)
    at /home/scpeters/osrf/gazebo_1.8/gazebo/transport/Node.hh:208
#5  0x000000000042aaa0 in main (argc=1, argv=0x7fff3d763768)
    at /home/scpeters/osrf/gazebo_1.8/tools/gzstats.cc:169
~~~
A pull request is forthcoming.

values.title: Transport blocked when establishing connection with gzclient and gzserver

content.raw:
When establishing connection between subscribers and publishers in  `ConnectionManager::ProcessMessage`, eventually a call is made to `Connection::Connect`  which can potentially be slow due to latency between client and server hence blocking the update.

This causes sensor publications to be held up,  as the result, atlas falls on the ground.
content.html:
When establishing connection between subscribers and publishers in ConnectionManager::ProcessMessage, eventually a call is made to Connection::Connect which can potentially be slow due to latency between client and server hence blocking the update.

This causes sensor publications to be held up, as the result, atlas falls on the ground.

content.raw:
From discussion of pull request #573:

I have seen the SensorManager_TEST.InitRemove segfault several times on my machine in the same way. In the backtraces, the seg-fault occurs in the sensor update thread making physics calls, like ODEMultiRayShape::UpdateCallback and dSpaceCollide2, while another thread is calling the sensor destructor.
Glancing at SensorManager,

[SensorContainer::RemoveSensor](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/eacff658f3ec5e89577ad00a10dfc03b75b2f87b/gazebo/sensors/SensorManager.cc?at=default#cl-578) locks SensorContainer::mutex before erasing sensors

[SensorContainer::RemoveSensors](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/eacff658f3ec5e89577ad00a10dfc03b75b2f87b/gazebo/sensors/SensorManager.cc?at=default#cl-619) does not lock anything before erasing sensors

[SensorContainer::RunLoop](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/eacff658f3ec5e89577ad00a10dfc03b75b2f87b/gazebo/sensors/SensorManager.cc?at=default#cl-439) uses a variety of mutexes, but it does not lock SensorContainer::mutex during updates.

My guess is that we need a mutex lock to prevent sensor deletion during an update.

content.html:
From discussion of pull request #573:

I have seen the SensorManager_TEST.InitRemove segfault several times on my machine in the same way. In the backtraces, the seg-fault occurs in the sensor update thread making physics calls, like ODEMultiRayShape::UpdateCallback and dSpaceCollide2, while another thread is calling the sensor destructor. Glancing at SensorManager,

SensorContainer::RemoveSensor locks SensorContainer::mutex before erasing sensors

SensorContainer::RemoveSensors does not lock anything before erasing sensors

SensorContainer::RunLoop uses a variety of mutexes, but it does not lock SensorContainer::mutex during updates.

My guess is that we need a mutex lock to prevent sensor deletion during an update.

Backtrace of selected threads:

values.title: With multiple `gzclient`s open, moving static models with gui manipulation tool in one `gzclient` does not update visuals in other `gzclient`s.

content.raw: e.g. see attached photo, the wall is moved away from it's original location in one `gzclient`, but the change did not propagate to other open `gzclient`s.
content.html: e.g. see attached photo, the wall is moved away from it's original location in one gzclient, but the change did not propagate to other open gzclients.

values.title: URDF to SDF converter skips collisions

content.raw:
The URDF to SDF coverter will only apply gazebo extensions to the first collision element in a link.

Example error (using DRCSim package):

`roscd atlas_sandia_hands && gzsdf print atlas_sandia_hands.urdf | head -n 45`
content.html:
The URDF to SDF coverter will only apply gazebo extensions to the first collision element in a link.

Example error (using DRCSim package):

roscd atlas_sandia_hands && gzsdf print atlas_sandia_hands.urdf | head -n 45

content.raw:
I have been seeing quite a bit of crashing of gazebo.  I started watching the process using top and saw that gzserver was continously growing in memory size.  This is with the current released version (1.8.2-1 / 2.6.3-1).  It doesn't show up until our software starts running, but continues even if our software is stopped.  Memory growth is about 0.3% per second for task 2.  Task 1 & task 3 don't show the same growth, so maybe it is a drcsim bug.

I just spent a some time isolating it.  It is also related to the ladar.  Running the laser_scan_assembler service and a client of that service is what triggers the growth.  Growth does continue after they are stopped.

I have attached a simple compiled client.  And here is the launch file for the service:

```
#!c++

<launch>
  <node type="laser_scan_assembler" pkg="laser_assembler"
        name="my_assembler">
    <remap from="scan" to="/multisense_sl/laser/scan"/>
    <param name="max_scans" type="int" value="60" />
    <param name="fixed_frame" type="string" value="/pelvis" />
    <param name="ignore_laser_skew" type="bool" value="false"/>
  </node>
</launch>
```
content.html:
I have been seeing quite a bit of crashing of gazebo. I started watching the process using top and saw that gzserver was continously growing in memory size. This is with the current released version (1.8.2-1 / 2.6.3-1). It doesn't show up until our software starts running, but continues even if our software is stopped. Memory growth is about 0.3% per second for task 2. Task 1 & task 3 don't show the same growth, so maybe it is a drcsim bug.

I just spent a some time isolating it. It is also related to the ladar. Running the laser_scan_assembler service and a client of that service is what triggers the growth. Growth does continue after they are stopped.

I have attached a simple compiled client. And here is the launch file for the service:

<launch>
  <node type="laser_scan_assembler" pkg="laser_assembler"
        name="my_assembler">
    <remap from="scan" to="/multisense_sl/laser/scan"/>
    <param name="max_scans" type="int" value="60" />
    <param name="fixed_frame" type="string" value="/pelvis" />
    <param name="ignore_laser_skew" type="bool" value="false"/>
  </node>
</launch>

values.title: gazebo 1.8.5 memory leak when visualizing contacts in mud

content.raw:
To reproduce:

1.  Start simulation (in SL):

        roslaunch atlas_utils vrc_task_2.launch gzname:=gzserver

1. Open gzclient remotely.
1. Move Atlas into mud pit.
1. Enable contacts visualization.

and memory usage should grow quite quickly for `gzserver`.
content.html:
To reproduce:

  1. Start simulation (in SL):

    roslaunch atlas_utils vrc_task_2.launch gzname:=gzserver

  2. Open gzclient remotely.

  3. Move Atlas into mud pit.
  4. Enable contacts visualization.

and memory usage should grow quite quickly for gzserver.

content.raw:
I have seen infrequent seg-faults of the transport_stress test in my overnight builds for a while (about 1 in 50). It occurs during teardown after an otherwise successful test.

Console output:
~~~
[ RUN      ] TransportStressTest.ManyNodes
Msg Waiting for master
Msg Connected to gazebo master @ http://127.0.0.1:11345
Msg Publicized address: 192.168.1.67
Dbg ServerFixture load in 0.02 seconds, timeout after 60 seconds
Msg Publish complete
Warning [Publisher.cc:144] Queue limit reached for topic /gazebo/default/physics/contacts, deleting message. This warning is printed only once.
Warning [Publisher.cc:144] Queue limit reached for topic /gazebo/default/diagnostics, deleting message. This warning is printed only once.
Msg Time to publish 10000 = 0 162833906
Msg Time to receive 10000000 = 3 412667086
Segmentation fault (core dumped)
~~~

I've just gotten a backtrace from a source build of gazebo_1.8.5 (6564bf3). The complaint seems to be an increment operator in [Publication::RemoveSubscription](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/6564bf34fc453f7d5a7aaa06ca18073d0a2d10cf/gazebo/transport/Publication.cc?at=gazebo_1.8#cl-187)

content.html:
I have seen infrequent seg-faults of the transport_stress test in my overnight builds for a while (about 1 in 50). It occurs during teardown after an otherwise successful test.

Console output:

[ RUN      ] TransportStressTest.ManyNodes
Msg Waiting for master
Msg Connected to gazebo master @ http://127.0.0.1:11345
Msg Publicized address: 192.168.1.67
Dbg ServerFixture load in 0.02 seconds, timeout after 60 seconds
Msg Publish complete
Warning [Publisher.cc:144] Queue limit reached for topic /gazebo/default/physics/contacts, deleting message. This warning is printed only once.
Warning [Publisher.cc:144] Queue limit reached for topic /gazebo/default/diagnostics, deleting message. This warning is printed only once.
Msg Time to publish 10000 = 0 162833906
Msg Time to receive 10000000 = 3 412667086
Segmentation fault (core dumped)

I've just gotten a backtrace from a source build of gazebo_1.8.5 (6564bf3). The complaint seems to be an increment operator in Publication::RemoveSubscription

values.title: Default GUI window size is too big

content.html:
The relevant code is here: #!/osrf/gazebo/src/d82f59e9abe91be9b4144f62bd181f5c17f27d77/gazebo/gui/MainWindow.cc?at=default#cl-193

The GUI window should automatically choose a size the is some portion of the desktop size. Many graphical applications open to full screen on default. If we do this, then we need to start saving GUI state, so that the GUI opens to the last size.

values.title: Consider lightweight data structure for logging

content.raw:
XML tags carry too much overhead. It increases memory usage and impacts performance.

Should consider other efficient, lightweight data structure for logging, such as JSON, protobuf, etc.
content.html:
XML tags carry too much overhead. It increases memory usage and impacts performance.

Should consider other efficient, lightweight data structure for logging, such as JSON, protobuf, etc.

content.raw:
Expose parameters for:

1) Precision

2) What models get logged

3) Hz rate for logging

4) What values get logged (pose, velocity, acceleration, wrench, joint angles, etc)
content.html:

content.raw:
When using a large min value in a ray sensor we can easily see in ROS RViz that the ranges reported are wrong. The min distance seems to be added twice in the MultiRangeShape, once in the Update function with the shortened fullRange and once in the GetRange function with the addition of GetMinRange.

Removing the addition of GetMinRange() from the MultiRangeShape::GetRange function seems to solves the problem. The visualization in RViz report aligned hits compared to a depth camera.

Related to issue #503
content.html:
When using a large min value in a ray sensor we can easily see in ROS RViz that the ranges reported are wrong. The min distance seems to be added twice in the MultiRangeShape, once in the Update function with the shortened fullRange and once in the GetRange function with the addition of GetMinRange.

Removing the addition of GetMinRange() from the MultiRangeShape::GetRange function seems to solves the problem. The visualization in RViz report aligned hits compared to a depth camera.

Related to issue #503

content.raw:
There are conflicting tags in the Xacro format and the SDF format that is embedded into URDFs using the <gazebo> elements.

Both Xacro and SDF have <include> tags, so when Xacro sees a SDF include tag it throws an error because they have different purposes and file paths.

For example, in my dummy RRBot I am including URDF files using:

```
#!bash
<include filename="$(find rrbot_description)/urdf/rrbot.gazebo" />
```


And In the rrbot.gazebo file I am including the Hoyoku sensor using:
```
#!bash
<include>
      <uri>model://hokuyo</uri>
</include> 
```

I get the error:
```
#!bash
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/opt/ros/groovy/stacks/xacro/xacro.py", line 35, in <module>
    xacro.main()
  File "/opt/ros/groovy/stacks/xacro/src/xacro.py", line 554, in main
    process_includes(doc, os.path.dirname(sys.argv[1]))
  File "/opt/ros/groovy/stacks/xacro/src/xacro.py", line 202, in process_includes
    raise XacroException("included file \"%s\" could not be opened: %s" % (filename, str(e)))
xacro.XacroException: included file "/home/dave/ros/misc/src/gazebo_ros_demos/rrbot_description/urdf/" could not be opened: [Errno 21] Is a directory: '/home/dave/ros/misc/src/gazebo_ros_demos/rrbot_description/urdf/'
Invalid <param> tag: Cannot load command parameter [robot_description]: command [/opt/ros/groovy/stacks/xacro/xacro.py '/home/dave/ros/misc/src/gazebo_ros_demos/rrbot_description/urdf/rrbot.xacro'] returned with code [1]. 

Param xml is <param command="$(find xacro)/xacro.py '$(find rrbot_description)/urdf/rrbot.xacro'" name="robot_description"/>
```

I can get everything to work if I convert the Xacro to URDF XML first, then add the SDF include statement manually...

Thoughts on how to fix this?

Reference:
http://ros.org/wiki/xacro#Including_other_xacro_files
http://gazebosim.org/sdf/dev.html

values.title: Possible SDF parser bug in wrong closed attribute

content.raw:
Below there is a piece of model, note that the tag <radius> wasn't closed correctly. Is it supposed that sdf parser warns about it?

When I try to put the model in the gazebo, I don't receive any warning or error message. The object is shown correctly but the collision behaviour is lost.

```
#!sdf

<link name="tree_branch">
        <pose>1.5 0 0.5  0 0 0</pose>
        <visual name="branch_visual">
            <geometry>
                <cylinder>
                    <radius> 0.2 </xxx>
                    <length> 1.0 </length>
                </cylinder>
            </geometry>
            <material>
                <script>
                    <uri>file://media/materials/scripts/gazebo.material</uri>
                    <name>Gazebo/Grey</name>
                </script>
            </material>
      </visual>
      
      <collision name="branch_col">
          <geometry>
              <cylinder>
                    <radius> 0.2 </radius>
                    <length> 1.0 </length>
                </cylinder>
          </geometry>
      </collision>
  </link>
```

values.title: Log files take an extremely long time to play back

content.raw: This has been the case for a while (at least since DRC quals), but has been on our back burner until now. If we are running at 0.6 real time for example, the state files play back at about 0.01 real time. This makes playing back logs as a means of reviewing our runs useless.
content.html: This has been the case for a while (at least since DRC quals), but has been on our back burner until now. If we are running at 0.6 real time for example, the state files play back at about 0.01 real time. This makes playing back logs as a means of reviewing our runs useless.

values.title: Adding robot_namespace to sdf nested models

content.raw:
This is a re-post of an issue for [gazebo_ros_pkgs](https://github.com/osrf/gazebo_ros_pkgs/issues/2#issuecomment-19277757), see that link.

Per John Hsu - we need to add robot namespace functionality inside of Gazebo's URDF parsing functionality in the Gazebo repo at 
```
gazebo/sdf/interface/parser_urdf.cc
```
content.html:
This is a re-post of an issue for gazebo_ros_pkgs, see that link.

Per John Hsu - we need to add robot namespace functionality inside of Gazebo's URDF parsing functionality in the Gazebo repo at 

gazebo/sdf/interface/parser_urdf.cc

values.title: Attributes of child elements are not copied if no element description is available

content.raw:
Attributes of unknown SDF elements (e.g. plugin configuration) should also be copied in the `sdf::copyChildren()` function in `sdf/interface/parser.cc`. The current version only copies attributes of elements that have a description.

I am using attributes in some plugin configuration elements and it took me a while to find out why I cannot access them in the plugin's Load() method any more...

I am using Gazebo version 1.5 shipped with groovy. In fuerte, using the old parser_deprecated.cc that has been removed in d7dbe92b6426674e33891035223605f390599dcb, having attributes in plugin child elements worked without problems.
content.html:
Attributes of unknown SDF elements (e.g. plugin configuration) should also be copied in the sdf::copyChildren() function in sdf/interface/parser.cc. The current version only copies attributes of elements that have a description.

I am using attributes in some plugin configuration elements and it took me a while to find out why I cannot access them in the plugin's Load() method any more...

I am using Gazebo version 1.5 shipped with groovy. In fuerte, using the old parser_deprecated.cc that has been removed in d7dbe92b6426674e33891035223605f390599dcb, having attributes in plugin child elements worked without problems.

content.raw: Running gzlog sends the logfile compression into a black hole, where you have no idea how far in the process the script is, and how much time is remaining.  This is a reminder in the form of a formal ticket for adding some kind of progress indicator on the compression process, if such a thing is possible.
content.html: Running gzlog sends the logfile compression into a black hole, where you have no idea how far in the process the script is, and how much time is remaining. This is a reminder in the form of a formal ticket for adding some kind of progress indicator on the compression process, if such a thing is possible.

content.raw: Gazebo logs should be able to be played back at a controlled speed (or semi-controlled, like real-time factor). Right now the filtered logs often play back way too fast, many times faster than real-time, and there is no good way to slow down playback.
content.html: Gazebo logs should be able to be played back at a controlled speed (or semi-controlled, like real-time factor). Right now the filtered logs often play back way too fast, many times faster than real-time, and there is no good way to slow down playback.

values.title: gzsdf: urdf parser ignores properties for links

content.raw:
My model has two caster weels, which are attached to the main body with fixed links (for simplicity). I have added Gazebo properties like this:

```
#!xml

  <gazebo reference="caster_front_link">
    <mu1>0.0</mu1>
    <mu2>0.0</mu2>
    <kp>100000000.0</kp>
    <kd>10000.0</kd>
  </gazebo>
```

After conversion to SDF those links seem to be merged with the main body and are transformed into collision objects. 

```
#!xml

    <link name='base_footprint'>
      [...]
      <collision name='base_footprint_geom_caster_back_link'>
        <pose>-0.135000 0.000000 0.019200 -1.570800 0.000000 0.000000</pose>
        <geometry>
          <cylinder>
            <length>0.017600</length>
            <radius>0.017000</radius>
          </cylinder>
        </geometry>
      </collision>
```

Unfortunately, the mu, mu2, kd and kp properties get lost and the caster are assigned high friction values (check inside simulation).

I'm using the latest version (1.8.6, compiled from source, default branch).

What can I do to fix this problem?

content.raw:
A mode for visualizing the collision model in place of the visual model would be nice - i.e. not a mixed mode with transparency like it is now, but one where you see just the collision model and can **optionally** enable transparency for the collision models.

An example illustrating what I mean is attached. (you're probably asking yourself "why isn't he simply creating a pull-request if he already has a picture showing what he wants?", and the answer to that is that the picture below was just a quick hack that modified the current collision visualization to use different material and disable visuals, but the goal would be to still keep the current mixed-mode collision visualization and offer the collision-only mode separately.)
content.html:
A mode for visualizing the collision model in place of the visual model would be nice - i.e. not a mixed mode with transparency like it is now, but one where you see just the collision model and can optionally enable transparency for the collision models.

An example illustrating what I mean is attached. (you're probably asking yourself "why isn't he simply creating a pull-request if he already has a picture showing what he wants?", and the answer to that is that the picture below was just a quick hack that modified the current collision visualization to use different material and disable visuals, but the goal would be to still keep the current mixed-mode collision visualization and offer the collision-only mode separately.)

values.title: CollisionTest in physics.cc has incorrect analytical answer

content.raw:
(I think John and I fixed this in the simbody branch but I don't want to lose track of it)
The test called "CollisionTest" in physics.cc attempts to provide an analytical solution to compare with the physics engine's result. However the analytical solution actually just duplicates ODE's incorrect answer, making it hard for us good guys to pass the test!

An initial impulse of 1 unit is delivered by providing a constant force of 1000 across the first dt=1ms integration step. That results in an acceleration a=f/m during that step. That should give v(.001)=a*dt and x(.001)=1/2 a dt^2. Instead x(.001) is given as v(.001)*dt. That is in fact what ODE will produce since it uses a fixed step first order semi-implicit method. But it is not the right answer. The correct answer is x(.001)=.0005, not .001. Note that this affects the time of impact also -- after 1s the block should be at x=.9995 rather than 1.

The test should be fixed to compare the numerical solution to the correct analytical solution. However, this could make it tricky for ODE to pass so will require some thought as to how much error is acceptable.

Sherm
content.html:
(I think John and I fixed this in the simbody branch but I don't want to lose track of it) The test called "CollisionTest" in physics.cc attempts to provide an analytical solution to compare with the physics engine's result. However the analytical solution actually just duplicates ODE's incorrect answer, making it hard for us good guys to pass the test!

An initial impulse of 1 unit is delivered by providing a constant force of 1000 across the first dt=1ms integration step. That results in an acceleration a=f/m during that step. That should give v(.001)=adt and x(.001)=1/2 a dt^2. Instead x(.001) is given as v(.001)dt. That is in fact what ODE will produce since it uses a fixed step first order semi-implicit method. But it is not the right answer. The correct answer is x(.001)=.0005, not .001. Note that this affects the time of impact also -- after 1s the block should be at x=.9995 rather than 1.

The test should be fixed to compare the numerical solution to the correct analytical solution. However, this could make it tricky for ODE to pass so will require some thought as to how much error is acceptable.

Sherm

values.title: Problems migrating plugin from Gazebo 1.5 to Gazebo 1.8.6

content.raw:
Crossposted from here: https://github.com/osrf/gazebo_ros_pkgs/issues/21

I have a simple differential drive plugin here based on the original differential drive plugin from the erratic_robot package: https://github.com/utexas-bwi/segbot_simulator/blob/master/segbot_gazebo_plugins/src/diff_drive_plugin.cc

This works as expected with simulator_gazebo-1.7.12 (Gazebo 1.5), but [GetWorldPose()](https://github.com/utexas-bwi/segbot_simulator/blob/master/segbot_gazebo_plugins/src/diff_drive_plugin.cc#L271) seems to be returning ~0 for position with gazebo_ros_pkgs (Gazebo 1.8.6). The position does not change even slightly over time, and the orientation changes somewhat arbitrarily. On the other hand the world linear and angular velocities are correct (but incorrectly transform to base_footprint as the orientation is arbitrary)

```
pose: 
  pose: 
    position: 
      x: 6.91499350184e-310
      y: 6.91499350199e-310
      z: 0.0
```

On the other hand `/gazebo/get_model/state` seems to be returning the correct value. Since it uses the `getWorldPose` under the hood, I am not sure what the difference is.

Please let me know if I should provide additional information to help debug this issue.
content.html:
Crossposted from here: https://github.com/osrf/gazebo_ros_pkgs/issues/21

I have a simple differential drive plugin here based on the original differential drive plugin from the erratic_robot package: https://github.com/utexas-bwi/segbot_simulator/blob/master/segbot_gazebo_plugins/src/diff_drive_plugin.cc

This works as expected with simulator_gazebo-1.7.12 (Gazebo 1.5), but GetWorldPose() seems to be returning ~0 for position with gazebo_ros_pkgs (Gazebo 1.8.6). The position does not change even slightly over time, and the orientation changes somewhat arbitrarily. On the other hand the world linear and angular velocities are correct (but incorrectly transform to base_footprint as the orientation is arbitrary)

pose: 
  pose: 
    position: 
      x: 6.91499350184e-310
      y: 6.91499350199e-310
      z: 0.0

On the other hand /gazebo/get_model/state seems to be returning the correct value. Since it uses the getWorldPose under the hood, I am not sure what the difference is.

Please let me know if I should provide additional information to help debug this issue.

values.title: Gazebo URDF Dom not compatible with Hydro

content.raw: The new version of urdfdom in ROS Hydro is causing Gazebo to segfault in the default branch. I'm not sure what exactly the issue is but we are hoping to release gazebo_ros_pkgs for Hydro so need this fixed.
content.html: The new version of urdfdom in ROS Hydro is causing Gazebo to segfault in the default branch. I'm not sure what exactly the issue is but we are hoping to release gazebo_ros_pkgs for Hydro so need this fixed.

content.raw:
We want to release [gazebo_ros_pkgs](https://github.com/osrf/gazebo_ros_pkgs) for Hydro and the freeze date is next week (June 29th). We need to decide how gazebo_ros_pkgs will depend on Gazebo for this release:

- Repackaged as a ROS package as its been done before
- Released into Ubuntu Universe

Is someone already working on this? I found this [Ubuntu packaging documentation](http://developer.ubuntu.com/packaging/html/).

Currently the [ROS build farm](http://ros.org/debbuild/hydro.html) has Gazebo 1.8.6 built for Hydro as a separate ROS package, though we need 1.9.0 for gazebo_ros to work correctly at runtime.
content.html:
We want to release gazebo_ros_pkgs for Hydro and the freeze date is next week (June 29th). We need to decide how gazebo_ros_pkgs will depend on Gazebo for this release:

  • Repackaged as a ROS package as its been done before
  • Released into Ubuntu Universe

Is someone already working on this? I found this Ubuntu packaging documentation.

Currently the ROS build farm has Gazebo 1.8.6 built for Hydro as a separate ROS package, though we need 1.9.0 for gazebo_ros to work correctly at runtime.

values.title: URDF parser does not handle the initial model pose

content.raw:
Spawning URDF models at poses other than the default does not work with Gazebo 1.8.6 and the spawn_model service in the current hydro-devel branch of [gazebo_ros_pkgs](https://github.com/osrf/gazebo_ros_pkgs/tree/45d28d9716a0694d3df3bfa16b56e7dd59fc8a81). The robot will always be spawned at the default 0 pose.

The `spawn_model` service handler in the gazebo_ros_api_plugin adds a `<origin>...</origin>` tag to the robot description and calls gazebo's factory service internally. I did not find any code in `parser_urdf.cc` that reads this tag and adds a `<pose>` tag to the SDF description. So this issue could IMHO be solved

1. by converting the `<origin>` tag to a `<pose>` tag in the URDF parser or
2. with a modification of the gazebo_ros_api_plugin in gazebo_ros package, e.g. by passing the model pose within a gazebo extension that the URDF parser does not touch.

As other elements use the `<origin>` tag too I assume that 1. is the intended behavior and model origin support has been dropped accidentally, as it used to work in the gazebo version shipped with groovy.
content.html:
Spawning URDF models at poses other than the default does not work with Gazebo 1.8.6 and the spawn_model service in the current hydro-devel branch of gazebo_ros_pkgs. The robot will always be spawned at the default 0 pose.

The spawn_model service handler in the gazebo_ros_api_plugin adds a <origin>...</origin> tag to the robot description and calls gazebo's factory service internally. I did not find any code in parser_urdf.cc that reads this tag and adds a <pose> tag to the SDF description. So this issue could IMHO be solved

  1. by converting the <origin> tag to a <pose> tag in the URDF parser or
  2. with a modification of the gazebo_ros_api_plugin in gazebo_ros package, e.g. by passing the model pose within a gazebo extension that the URDF parser does not touch.

As other elements use the <origin> tag too I assume that 1. is the intended behavior and model origin support has been dropped accidentally, as it used to work in the gazebo version shipped with groovy.

values.title: Running Camera Drivers without X Server Causes Segfault

content.raw:
I ran Gazebo 1.5.0 just fine with no GUI, launching the PR2 through ROS. 

However, when I used the same launch file (again with the no gui option) but when logged into the same machine over SSH, the instance of Gazebo segfaulted immediately after I spawn the PR2. 

The problem disappears when I disable the cameras in the PR2 urdf.
content.html:
I ran Gazebo 1.5.0 just fine with no GUI, launching the PR2 through ROS.

However, when I used the same launch file (again with the no gui option) but when logged into the same machine over SSH, the instance of Gazebo segfaulted immediately after I spawn the PR2.

The problem disappears when I disable the cameras in the PR2 urdf.

content.raw:
I'm new to gazebo and I'm trying to launch a `gzserver` and a `gzclient` in two computers in the same network. Both machines are running Ubuntu 12.04, and the installation method I have used in both was the advanced package tool `apt`.

Both machines are configured with the same environment variables:
```
GAZEBO_MASTER_URI="http://192.168.96.43:11345"
GAZEBO_MODEL_DATABASE_URI="http://gazebosim.org/models"
GAZEBO_PLUGIN_PATH="/usr/lib/gazebo-1.8/plugins"
GAZEBO_RESOURCE_PATH="/usr/share/gazebo-1.8:/usr/share/gazebo_models"
```
As indicated in various tutorials and webpages, it is possible to run server and client in different machines, but I get the following errors:

in `gzserver`:


```
Gazebo multi-robot simulator, version 1.8.6
Copyright (C) 2013 Open Source Robotics Foundation.
Released under the Apache 2 License.
http://gazebosim.org

Msg Waiting for master
Msg Connected to gazebo master @ http://192.168.96.43:11345
Msg Publicized address: 192.168.96.43
Error [RenderEngine.cc:607] Can't open display:
Warning [RenderEngine.cc:86] Unable to create X window. Rendering will be disabled
```

and in `gzclient` i get:


```
Gazebo multi-robot simulator, version 1.8.6
Copyright (C) 2013 Open Source Robotics Foundation.
Released under the Apache 2 License.
http://gazebosim.org

Msg Waiting for master
Msg Connected to gazebo master @ http://192.168.96.43:11345
Msg Publicized address: 192.168.96.45
Warning [RenderEngine.cc:687] GLSL is missing.Fixed function rendering will be used.
Segmentation fault (core dumped)
```

as can be seen, the program crashes with a segmentation fault.

Could you please instruct me on how to get two computers in the same network working, one as a server and one or more as clients?

There is any tutorial covering that topics?

Thanks

content.raw:
Currently, the LIDAR simulated by gazebo assumes an instantaneous scan of the environment, however a real LIDAR takes a finite time to take a scan. To accurately simulate the real world and test our LIDAR processing code it would be advantageous to have the LIDAR scan be distorted by the motion of the LIDAR during the scan.

We understand that doing an accurate simulation would involve having to have a simulation tick between each ray taken by the LIDAR and doing a single ray cast every time, making the simulation very slow. While this would still be a nice-to-have for debugging, a faster solution could involve using the current velocity, with respect to world, of the LIDAR to distort the scan (thereby assuming a constant velocity).
content.html:
Currently, the LIDAR simulated by gazebo assumes an instantaneous scan of the environment, however a real LIDAR takes a finite time to take a scan. To accurately simulate the real world and test our LIDAR processing code it would be advantageous to have the LIDAR scan be distorted by the motion of the LIDAR during the scan.

We understand that doing an accurate simulation would involve having to have a simulation tick between each ray taken by the LIDAR and doing a single ray cast every time, making the simulation very slow. While this would still be a nice-to-have for debugging, a faster solution could involve using the current velocity, with respect to world, of the LIDAR to distort the scan (thereby assuming a constant velocity).

content.raw:
For debugging purposes, it is really advantageous to be able to stop then rewind and playback the simulation and scrub back and forward to see what went wrong.

A more advanced version could notify the controller of a rewind event and allow simulation starting from a previous point (possibly allowing for a change in controller parameters).
content.html:
For debugging purposes, it is really advantageous to be able to stop then rewind and playback the simulation and scrub back and forward to see what went wrong.

A more advanced version could notify the controller of a rewind event and allow simulation starting from a previous point (possibly allowing for a change in controller parameters).

See here: #!/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/557/sonar-and-force-torque-sensors/diff#comment-338914

The solution to this should go into gazebo_2.0

values.title: uneven sdf model updates cuase compatabilty issues, leading up to crash

content.raw:
Some of the latest sdf models are version 1.4 while others remain at 1.3 and 1.2. This cuases conflict when trying to run a simluation environment that uses different model versions.

~~~
exmaple: roslaunch atlas_utils atlas_drc_vehicle_fire_hose.launch 

Warning [parser.cc:361] Converting a deprecated SDF source[/usr/share/drcsim-2.6/gazebo_models/environments/vrc_firehose_long/model.sdf].
Warning [Converter.cc:58]   Version[1.3] to Version[1.4]
  Please use the gzsdf tool to update your SDF files.
    $ gzsdf convert [sdf_file]
Warning [parser.cc:361] Converting a deprecated SDF source[/usr/share/drcsim-2.6/gazebo_models/environments/vrc_standpipe/model.sdf].
Warning [Converter.cc:58]   Version[1.3] to Version[1.4]
  Please use the gzsdf tool to update your SDF files.
    $ gzsdf convert [sdf_file]
Warning [parser.cc:361] Converting a deprecated SDF source[/usr/share/drcsim-2.6/gazebo_models/environments/vrc_valve/model.sdf].
Warning [Converter.cc:58]   Version[1.3] to Version[1.4]
  Please use the gzsdf tool to update your SDF files.
    $ gzsdf convert [sdf_file]
Warning [gazebo_main.cc:62] escalating to SIGKILL on client
~~~

The drc_vehicle is a sdf 1.4 envrionment model, and for some reason cannot work with older model versions asgazebo continues to crash each time it tries to open.

content.raw:
Connection:headerBuffer is allocated 8 bytes, but later, in Connection::EnqueueMsg we allow to write up to 8+1 bytes (probably for the final \0). This causes hundreds of valgrind errors, and it might cause the program to crash.
imho headerBuffer should be allocated to a size of HEADER_LENGTH + 1. After this fix, valgrind does not complain any more


thanks
```
#!c++

  this->headerBuffer = new char[HEADER_LENGTH];

  snprintf(this->headerBuffer, HEADER_LENGTH + 1, "%08x",
      static_cast<unsigned int>(_buffer.size()));

```

content.html: See this question: http://answers.gazebosim.org/question/3424/multiple-worlds-on-one-gzserver-instance/?comment=3443#comment-3443

content.raw:
Test case:

1) Create two subscribers to the same topic in different processes.

2) Create a publisher that publishes a message on the topic, and then immediately quits.

Occasionally, one of the subscribers will not get the message due to communication delays (processing the connections between subscribers and publishers is asynchronous). 

A publisher can call WaitForConnection, but this will wait for only the first connection. We could extend Master to tell a publisher the number of current subscribers on a topic. WaitForConnection could then wait for all the connections, with a timeout.
content.html:
Test case:

1) Create two subscribers to the same topic in different processes.

2) Create a publisher that publishes a message on the topic, and then immediately quits.

Occasionally, one of the subscribers will not get the message due to communication delays (processing the connections between subscribers and publishers is asynchronous).

A publisher can call WaitForConnection, but this will wait for only the first connection. We could extend Master to tell a publisher the number of current subscribers on a topic. WaitForConnection could then wait for all the connections, with a timeout.

values.title: gazebo::init() not called before SDF parser

content.raw:
(on the `gazebo_1.9` branch)

The crash described in [sdformat issue #7](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/issue/7/crash-when-parsing-urdf) is apparently caused by out-of-order initialization in Gazebo.  The call to `sdf::setFindCallback()` in `gazebo::init()` doesn't (always) get called prior to invoking the SDF parser.
content.html:
(on the gazebo_1.9 branch)

The crash described in sdformat issue #7 is apparently caused by out-of-order initialization in Gazebo. The call to sdf::setFindCallback() in gazebo::init() doesn't (always) get called prior to invoking the SDF parser.

There is an alternative version of the function with takes a `common::Time` as a timeout argument, but it's only being used by [gzlog.cc:959](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/a92e30bd1d5f9bb3162be05cc910da0843892a03/tools/gzlog.cc?at=default#cl-959).

The function is called without a timeout in the following places:

* [Scene.cc:289](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/a92e30bd1d5f9bb3162be05cc910da0843892a03/gazebo/rendering/Scene.cc?at=default#cl-289)
* [Transport.cc:212](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/a92e30bd1d5f9bb3162be05cc910da0843892a03/gazebo/transport/Transport.cc?at=default#cl-212)
* [Node.hh:54](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/a92e30bd1d5f9bb3162be05cc910da0843892a03/gazebo/transport/Node.hh?at=default#cl-54)
* [test/ServerFixture.hh:174-175](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/a92e30bd1d5f9bb3162be05cc910da0843892a03/test/ServerFixture.hh?at=default#cl-174)
* [test/regression/state_log.cc:83](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/a92e30bd1d5f9bb3162be05cc910da0843892a03/test/regression/state_log.cc?at=default#cl-83)

* [test/regression/transport.cc:118](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/a92e30bd1d5f9bb3162be05cc910da0843892a03/test/regression/transport.cc?at=default#cl-118)

Seeing Scene.cc in this list makes me think of issue #681 (blank gzclient windows on startup).
content.html:

The function is called without a timeout in the following places:

  • gzfactory.cc:118
  • gzfactory.cc:156
  • Scene.cc:289

content.raw:
There are numerous files that will fail to install on case-insensitive filesystems, such as `rendering/rendering.hh` and `rendering/Rendering.hh`. Note that this includes Mac OS X, which uses a case-preserving but not case-sensitive filesystem by default.

A fix has been tested in the [osx](#!/osrf/gazebo/compare/osx..default#diff) branch, that renames `Rendering.hh` to `RenderingIface.hh`.
content.html:
There are numerous files that will fail to install on case-insensitive filesystems, such as rendering/rendering.hh and rendering/Rendering.hh. Note that this includes Mac OS X, which uses a case-preserving but not case-sensitive filesystem by default.

A fix has been tested in the osx branch, that renames Rendering.hh to RenderingIface.hh.

values.title: Gazebo's find_package rules do no expose plugins

content.raw:
gazebo should expose the optional components like other libraries with the COMPONENTS keyword, in particular the plugin libraries. 

So it would be like:
find_package(gazebo REQUIRED COMPONENTS Core CameraPlugin)

This would allow the find_package to correctly populate the GAZEBO_LIBRARIES variable to include the plugins instead of requiring the downstream user to call

set_target_properties(TARGET_NAME PROPERTIES LINK_FLAGS "${ld_flags}")

for every target.  And then you have to hard code the plugin library name in the TARGET_LINK_LIBRARIES call.  

The default if you don't pass any components is that you get all components.  This is patterend off of Boost and several other libraries.
content.html:
gazebo should expose the optional components like other libraries with the COMPONENTS keyword, in particular the plugin libraries.

So it would be like: find_package(gazebo REQUIRED COMPONENTS Core CameraPlugin)

This would allow the find_package to correctly populate the GAZEBO_LIBRARIES variable to include the plugins instead of requiring the downstream user to call

set_target_properties(TARGET_NAME PROPERTIES LINK_FLAGS "${ld_flags}")

for every target. And then you have to hard code the plugin library name in the TARGET_LINK_LIBRARIES call.

The default if you don't pass any components is that you get all components. This is patterend off of Boost and several other libraries.

values.title: gazebo slow at loading multiple object instances

content.raw:
Loading a large number of instances of the same object (e.g. all the cinder blocks for DRC Trial Task 2 as shown in the attached image) causes gzclient to accumulate large amounts of memory (3.6GB for the demonstrated case) and it takes ~10 minutes to add all the models to the world after loading the preview of the model (i.e. you click on the model in the list, it takes half a minute to load the preview of the model, but then it takes another ~10 minutes to add the objects to the chosen location).

Given that these are all the exact same objects just with different transforms I would not expect it to consume 3.6GB and take 10 minutes to add them to the world. Does gazebo load a unique instance for each object / 3d model instead of loading it once and using multiple instances?
content.html:
Loading a large number of instances of the same object (e.g. all the cinder blocks for DRC Trial Task 2 as shown in the attached image) causes gzclient to accumulate large amounts of memory (3.6GB for the demonstrated case) and it takes ~10 minutes to add all the models to the world after loading the preview of the model (i.e. you click on the model in the list, it takes half a minute to load the preview of the model, but then it takes another ~10 minutes to add the objects to the chosen location).

Given that these are all the exact same objects just with different transforms I would not expect it to consume 3.6GB and take 10 minutes to add them to the world. Does gazebo load a unique instance for each object / 3d model instead of loading it once and using multiple instances?

content.raw:
The setup.sh file is currently required to be sourced before running gazebo. This is a common source of user error when attempting to run gazebo, and is also not recommended for packages that are included in debian.

We can bake in the default paths at build time and allow the user to override those values with environment variables. The setup.sh file can still be installed to illustrate the default values of the environment variables, but it wouldn't be necessary to source it before running gazebo.
content.html:
The setup.sh file is currently required to be sourced before running gazebo. This is a common source of user error when attempting to run gazebo, and is also not recommended for packages that are included in debian.

We can bake in the default paths at build time and allow the user to override those values with environment variables. The setup.sh file can still be installed to illustrate the default values of the environment variables, but it wouldn't be necessary to source it before running gazebo.

content.raw:
From @Progtologist in pull request #178:

`find @CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX@/share -path @CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX@/share/gazebo-'*'/setup.sh | sort | tail -n 1` is very slow and causes a significant lag if inserted in .bashrc A better solution should be provided. A simple workaround is to add the argument `-type f` in find to specify not to search folder names.

Similar to [drcsim issue #274](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/drcsim/issue/274).

values.title: Most warnings and errors are not logged to file

content.html: gzmsg, gzdbg, gzwarn, and gzerr print to console but aren't written into a file. They should be.

values.title: gztopic list does not work well via ssh

content.raw:
the following bash script fails to execute:


```
#!bash

#!/bin/bash

ssh -o UserKnownHostsFile=/dev/null -o StrictHostKeyChecking=no -i /home/ubuntu/cloudsim/key-sim.pem ubuntu@10.0.0.51  ". /usr/share/drcsim/setup.sh; timeout -k 1 5 gztopic list"

```
The problem is in the parsing of the command line arguments. In the case of this script, the isatty call returns false and the parsing goes into a loop (waiting for an EOF that never comes).

The workaround is to pass -n to ssh (redirect input to /dev/null) but that's neither obvious or intuitive.
content.html:
the following bash script fails to execute:

#!/bin/bash

ssh -o UserKnownHostsFile=/dev/null -o StrictHostKeyChecking=no -i /home/ubuntu/cloudsim/key-sim.pem ubuntu@10.0.0.51  ". /usr/share/drcsim/setup.sh; timeout -k 1 5 gztopic list"

The problem is in the parsing of the command line arguments. In the case of this script, the isatty call returns false and the parsing goes into a loop (waiting for an EOF that never comes).

The workaround is to pass -n to ssh (redirect input to /dev/null) but that's neither obvious or intuitive.

content.raw:
There are many places where the `.so` extension is assumed through out gazebo and the related packages.

For example, when loading a plugin with the `-s` command line option it is recommended that users give `libfoo.so`. On OS X this will not work because the file name is likely called `libfoo.dylib`. This is a problem in the `gazebo_ros` package for example:

https://github.com/ros-simulation/gazebo_ros_pkgs/blob/hydro-devel/gazebo_ros/scripts/gazebo#L7

Other places include specifying plugins in the urdf description of robots, for example:

https://github.com/davetcoleman/baxter_common/blob/development/baxter_description/urdf/baxter.urdf#L1230

Any time `.so` is hardcoded or assumed there will be a break on OS X.

In ROS we use pluginlib (which uses class_loader):

https://github.com/ros/pluginlib
https://github.com/ros/class_loader

Pluginlib works around this problem by only specifying the first part of the library name, leaving off the suffix. Then pluginlib looks for the correct thing based on the OS:

See the path attribute:
http://ros.org/wiki/pluginlib#pluginlib.2BAC8-pluginlib_groovy.The_Plugin_Description_File

I am creating this issue to help track what needs to be done to become agnostic to the dynamic library extension being used.
content.html:
There are many places where the .so extension is assumed through out gazebo and the related packages.

For example, when loading a plugin with the -s command line option it is recommended that users give libfoo.so. On OS X this will not work because the file name is likely called libfoo.dylib. This is a problem in the gazebo_ros package for example:

https://github.com/ros-simulation/gazebo_ros_pkgs/blob/hydro-devel/gazebo_ros/scripts/gazebo#L7

Other places include specifying plugins in the urdf description of robots, for example:

https://github.com/davetcoleman/baxter_common/blob/development/baxter_description/urdf/baxter.urdf#L1230

Any time .so is hardcoded or assumed there will be a break on OS X.

In ROS we use pluginlib (which uses class_loader):

https://github.com/ros/pluginlib https://github.com/ros/class_loader

Pluginlib works around this problem by only specifying the first part of the library name, leaving off the suffix. Then pluginlib looks for the correct thing based on the OS:

See the path attribute: http://ros.org/wiki/pluginlib#pluginlib.2BAC8-pluginlib_groovy.The_Plugin_Description_File

I am creating this issue to help track what needs to be done to become agnostic to the dynamic library extension being used.
